content: When is the meeting going to happen next week? If we stick to 1515 UTC, that would move it 1h earlier for me, which is okay. But if e.g. the compiler team meeting does NOT stick to UTC, but shift with DST (but then DST in which state/country? AFAIK not even all US states shift at the same time), that would make the two overlap.
we could also move to 1615 UTC, which means the time wouldn't change for anyone who goes out of DST this weekend
usually I selfishly anchor everything to the US
seems like the compiler team mtg will stay on US time
which US time? you have 4 timezones and AFAIK states have autonomy for DST
i.e., youre not being helpful ;)
for the purposes of this discussion, it is irrelevant, but ok — Boston time :)
I suppose it's technically true that some locales do DST differently
well it is relevant because when Boston goes in and out of DST might be different than, dunno, New Jersey
basically: the time in the calendar invite
which is presently anchored to New York =)
I'd like to have your trust in that invite actually being interpreted correctly across DST changes
but I dont :)

@RalfJ while it is nominally true that DST is a states issue, the only state that chooses not to do it at present is Arizona. So, there is one precise notion of an "Eastern Time" (and, for that matter, a "Pacific Time").
(There is not one "Mountain Time" because half the year Arizona's mountain time agrees with "Pacific Time" and the other half it agrees with the rest of "Mountain Time" :wink:)
this stuff makes my head hurt :head_bandage:
Mountain is... 1 or 2 offset from Eastern?
see, if you just use UTC offsets you dont have to assume people know US politics :P
or geograhpy
or both, actually, it turns out
I think we should abolish all time zones and DST and just have half the world wake up in the night time
just not my half
we should use 25h days
so the half that wakes up at night moves slowly over the globe

Mountain is... 1 or 2 offset from Eastern?

Mountain is UTC-7 or UTC-6 (DST), but Arizona is always UTC-7. I didn't really specify where they were because it wasn't important besides "Not Eastern Time." :wink:
Something something, my costal elitism.
however, US DST is different from EU DST
we go out of DST this weekend
you seem to do it one week later
(or so google said, when I just asked it)
yes
so I'd still prefer using UTC^^
for communication
dont care about what it is pinned to
this is why I prefer pinning to a locale
I think UTC is the only locale that we can reasonably expect everyone to know
because I don't really know my UTC offsets :) I know the relative offsets to other places...
like, I honestly dont want to also have to remember when US goes into/out of DST
I agree that makes a measure of sense =) mostly I lean on calendars for this... regardless, it would conflict with compiler mtg I think if we don't leave it as is?
by leave as is you mean stick with UTC 1515 for one more week and then go to UTC 1415?
well there is no mtg next week
so in two weeks it'd still be 1515 or would it be 1415?
whatever the calendar invite says :)
sigh
also @Nicole Mazzuca said they wanted a bit earlier
AFAIK it was for them that we start 1515 and not earlier, so I'd be fine going to 1500
wfm
I do see the logic of UTC — we could move compiler meeting and anchor it to UTC too — I don't care really, just want to do the same thing for both (and have it reflected in the calendar invite).
yeah it makes sense to do the pinning consistently across rust teams
and I guess for now that means US\Arizona
but that means we all rely on our US friends to notify us when the UTC offset changes :)
It means US/Boston since Boston is the center of the (@nikomatsakis) universe :wink:
confirm :)
well it wouldn't make sense to pin on my timezone since i'm half european timezone half west coast time...
see also the discussion in #t-compiler here
which revealed some downsides to both approaches
and did not yet seem to reach a firm conclusion
